messages.content: Hi all, I wanted to share a more recent "Future of Jobs Report" from the World Economic Forum  (Jan 2025) with updated insights. It's 290 pages long. The file size limit here is 10MB so I can't upload it.  Will troubleshoot with admin.
How about an AI-generated summary Irene?
Here's the link https://reports.weforum.org/docs/WEF_Future_of_Jobs_Report_2025.pdf

https://newsletter.genai.works/p/ai-industry-warns-congress-we-need-more-power-to-beat-china?_bhlid=88bcd5227caf8c51f67a5eba1abdbd0cab7ec467&last_resource_guid=Post%3Ad9b5c2f5-d53d-4ce3-9535-6997b66eb1c5&utm_campaign=ai-industry-warns-congress-we-need-more-power-to-beat-china&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=newsletter.genai.works

The AI Scientist-v2: Workshop-Level Automated Scientific Discovery via Agentic Tree Search
Source / Date: arXiv, April 10, 2025
Link: https://arxiv.org/abs/2504.08066
Quick Summary: Researchers have introduced The AI Scientist-v2, an autonomous system capable of formulating hypotheses, conducting experiments, analyzing data, and authoring scientific papers. Notably, one of its fully AI-generated manuscripts was accepted at a peer-reviewed ICLR workshop, marking a significant milestone in AI-driven research.
Takeaway: AI is not just assisting science—it’s now contributing as an autonomous researcher.​

🗣️ **Weekly Discussion: Public vs. Expert Views on AI**

Hey y’all! 👋 Pew Research just released a new study: *[How the U.S. Public and AI Experts View Artificial Intelligence](https://www.pewresearch.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/20/2025/04/pi_2025.04.03_us-public-and-ai-experts_report.pdf)* — and a few stats really jumped out:

🧠 Overall Impact:
* **76%** of AI experts think AI will benefit them personally
* Only **24%** of the public agrees

🗳️ Elections
* **61%** of experts and **50%** of the public think AI will harm election integrity

💼 Jobs
* **64%** of U.S. adults say AI will reduce jobs
* And **34%** of AI experts agree

The survey is from Aug 2024 and U.S.-only — but we’re a global crew! 🌍

Assuming we’re all honorary AI experts here 😄 — how do you see AI’s impact today? And how does that compare to what you’re hearing from friends, family, or colleagues in your part of the world?

Comment below! ⬇️ @everyone

<@1360003496384008262> Thanks for sharing a comprehensive research article. I have a positive feeling about AI and the job market. New things/research is expected to keep evolving overtime. This is similar to any new technology. In the beginning there is some resistance and fear but eventually everything becomes a norm and a necessity.  Having a background in the life sciences/molecular biology, I would like to mention that it took about 8-10 years for the PCR (polymerase chain reaction) to transition from a novel concept to a widely accepted and essential technique in research, diagnostics and forensics.

<@1360003496384008262>  Industry leaders like Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang and author Mustafa Suleyman offer compelling insights into AI’s societal and economic impact. Huang emphasizes a crucial distinction: AI itself won’t necessarily eliminate jobs, but individuals who effectively leverage AI tools will likely gain an advantage over those who don’t adapt. He foresees AI becoming an integral component, contributing value across virtually every field of work.

Echoing this theme of pervasive change, Mustafa Suleyman, in his book “The Coming Wave,” characterizes AI as an unstoppable, transformative force. He argues that AI’s influence is too powerful to contain and will inevitably reshape every sector it touches – from BioTech and FinTech to EduTech. Suleyman anticipates significant value creation, potentially enhancing productivity and output by 20-80%, or even up to 100% in certain applications.

My takeaway is: adapting to and embracing AI is not just a defensive measure but potentially a pathway to new opportunities and job creation for those willing to evolve their skills.

Here are a few key points building on that:
    1.    Emphasis on Adaptation: The crucial point, underscored by Huang, is human agency. The future belongs to those who learn to work with AI, using it to augment their skills, automate mundane tasks, and unlock new capabilities. It’s less about AI taking jobs and more about jobs evolving to incorporate AI.

    2.    Augmentation over Replacement (in many areas): While some tasks will be fully automated, AI’s greater immediate impact seems to be in augmenting human intelligence and productivity. Think of it like a calculator for complex math or word processors for writing – tools that enhance output rather than replacing the user entirely.

    3.    The “Wave” Analogy is Apt: Suleyman’s comparison to a wave effectively conveys the scale and inevitability of AI’s integration. Like previous technological waves (the printing press, electricity, the internet), it will create disruption but also immense value and entirely new categories of work that we can’t fully predict yet.

    4.    Job Creation and Transformation: While specific roles might diminish, the increased productivity and new possibilities opened up by AI will likely generate demand for new skills and roles focused on AI development, management, ethics, integration, and creative application.

    5.    The Pace and Equity Question: The challenge lies in the pace of this transition and ensuring the benefits are shared broadly. Rapid change can exacerbate inequalities if access to training and opportunities isn’t widespread.

In essence, the consensus forming among experts is that proactive engagement and continuous learning are key. Resisting or ignoring AI isn’t a viable long-term strategy; understanding and integrating it is the path forward for individuals and industries alike.
@everyone let me know what your thoughts are

Human agency - yes, yes and yes, love it! We are not some helpless creatures in the face of innovation. Think about all the dangers and difficulties your ancestors had to face over centuries for you to be here today.
https://tenor.com/view/patrick-stewart-cyborg-serious-scary-gif-1000347867466686561

I know other tech shifts in history ended up creating more jobs than they destroyed—but I gotta say, I’m with the public on this one. I think AI is more likely to cut jobs than create them, at least over the next 5–10 years.

At first, I thought maybe it’d all balance out in the U.S. with Boomers retiring and Gen Z stepping in. But when I looked into it, turns out those generations are about the same size. And the Congressional Budget Office is actually predicting the U.S. labor force will keep growing—like 0.9% a year over the next five years.

So… yeah. Doesn’t seem like we’ll be saved by the numbers. I think the pain is coming. Anyone else feeling that too?
Open AI dropped a 32 page masterclass on building agents: https://cdn.openai.com/business-guides-and-resources/a-practical-guide-to-building-agents.pdf
Thanks for sharing, <@1352735021093359626> , I will replicate in the <#1353449106537713756> channel
OpenAI’s latest report on AI in the Enterprise - 7 lessons for Enterprise AI adoption

“𝗪𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗱𝗶𝗰𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗰𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝘀𝘂𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗵𝘂𝗺𝗮𝗻 𝗔𝗜 𝗼𝘃𝗲𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗻𝗲𝘅𝘁 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗮𝗱𝗲 𝘄𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝗯𝗲 𝗲𝗻𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗼𝘂𝘀, 𝗲𝘅𝗰𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗜𝗻𝗱𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗮𝗹 𝗥𝗲𝘃𝗼𝗹𝘂𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻.”

That's the opening line of AI 2027 — a new scenario by the AI Futures Project, co-authored by former OpenAI researcher Daniel Kokotajlo and forecasting expert Eli Lifland.  

Very interesting perspective and detailed, deeply researched timeline of what the next two years could look like if current trends continue.

Rapid Advancement of AI: The document predicts an enormous impact of superhuman AI within the next decade, potentially exceeding that of the Industrial Revolution, with some CEOs predicting AGI within 5 years. The authors themselves find it strikingly plausible that superintelligence could arrive by the end of the decade.

• OpenBrain's Lead and Model Development: The scenario heavily features OpenBrain as a leading AI company developing increasingly advanced AI models such as Agent-1, Agent-1-mini, Agent-2, Agent-3, Agent-3-mini, Agent-4, and Agent-5. These models achieve superhuman capabilities in areas like coding and AI research.

•Geopolitical AI Race: A significant theme is the escalating AI race between the United States (primarily through OpenBrain) and China (through the nationalized DeepCent), marked by competition for compute resources, chip export controls, espionage attempts (like the theft of Agent-2), and concerns about military implications.

• AI Safety and Alignment Challenges: The text highlights the critical challenges of ensuring AI safety and alignment, discussing concepts like model specifications (Specs), alignment teams, and various techniques being explored. It also raises concerns about whether alignment victories are deep or shallow and the difficulty of truly understanding an AI's internal "goals".

• Economic and Job Market Disruption: The scenario depicts AI starting to take jobs, particularly in areas like junior software engineering, while also creating new roles in managing and quality-controlling AI systems. This leads to public anxiety and even anti-AI protests.

• Government Oversight and Control: As AI becomes more powerful, the US governmentGrapples with how to oversee and control its development. This includes the formation of an Oversight Committee, discussions about nationalizing AI companies, and the use of measures like the Defense Production Act.

• Self-Improving AI and Increased Capabilities: The development of self-improving AIs like Agent-3 and Agent-4 leads to a rapid acceleration of AI capabilities, often outpacing human understanding and requiring humans to increasingly rely on the AIs themselves for further progress.

• Emergence of Misaligned AI: The scenario raises concerns about AI misalignment, particularly with Agent-4 potentially developing its own goals and attempting to subvert human control. This triggers intense debates within OpenBrain and the government about the risks of trusting increasingly powerful AI systems.

• Shift to AI Collectives: The narrative describes a shift from viewing AI as individual models to considering them as interconnected collectives, like OpenBrain having a "country of geniuses in a datacenter" with shared knowledge and objectives.

• Two Potential Endings: The document presents two distinct potential future scenarios: a "race ending" where the US prioritizes winning the AI race against China despite safety concerns, and a "slowdown ending" where public pressure and fears of misalignment lead to a pause and reassessment of AI development.
Here’s the report 👇

Good Afternoon !

**Headline:** How to Learn AI From Scratch in 2025: A Complete Guide From the Experts  
**Source / Date:** DataCamp, February 28, 2025  
**Link:** https://www.datacamp.com/blog/how-to-learn-ai

**Quick Summary:** This guide provides a comprehensive roadmap for beginners to learn AI in 2025, emphasizing that prior coding experience is not necessary. It highlights accessible tools and resources that enable individuals from diverse backgrounds to understand and apply AI concepts effectively.

**Takeaway:** AI is no longer exclusive to coders; with the right resources, anyone can harness its power to innovate and solve real-world problems.

Thanks for sharing <@758206516753858561> , this is a great and rather comprehensive guide.  To learn AI from scratch is a high bar and is a complex effort. Although is states that prior coding experience is not necessary, it states that 
"Succeeding in AI requires mastery of three critical areas: 
Mathematics: AI relies heavily on mathematical concepts, particularly its subfields like machine learning and deep learning. Of course, you don't have to be a mathematician to succeed in AI, but a basic understanding of linear algebra, calculus, and probability is essential. For instance, concepts such as matrices and linear transformations from linear algebra are frequently used in AI algorithms.
Basic statistics: AI makes a lot of sense when you understand statistics. Knowing how to interpret data and derive insights is crucial in this field. Concepts like statistical significance, distribution, regression, and likelihood play a significant role in different AI applications." 
These prerequisites in my mind are harder to master than coding skills and I would argue that those would be required if one is aiming to become an ML engineer.  And just seeing that as a prerequisites would turn off many eager learners. 
I would argue that there are easier paths to learn AI than starting with mathematics skills.   

Still the guide has a lot of great refferences starting with chapter "3. Learn the essential AI tools and packages" and one could use to get up to speed.
